bibl.title: Letter from Frederick T. van Beuren, Jr., to Mabel H. Lazear, November 15, 1930

div1.p: Van Beuren requests a photograph of Lazear to use in creating a bas-relief portrait for a memorial.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick T. van Beuren, Jr., to Mabel H. Lazear, November 15, 1930
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
Columbia University
College of Physicians and Surgeons
630 WEST 168TH STREET, NEW YORK
November 15, 1930.
Mrs. Mabel M. Lazear,
6 Oakvale Avenue,
Berkeley,
California.
My dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
Dr. Aristides Agramonte, of Havana, was good
enough to furnish me with your address and I am writ-
ing to ask whether you have by any chance a photograph
of Dr. Jesse Lazear, which shows his face more or less
in profile. If you have such a photograph and would
be good enough to lend it to us temporarily, it would
greatly facilitate a plan which we have in mind to
have made a bronze plaque, which would hang in our
Student's Room as a memorial of Dr. Jesse Lazear and
his splendid achievement in the work of discovery of
the transmission of yellow fever. I should like, if
possible, to have this memorial carry a bas-relief
portrait of Dr. Lazear's head, but I have only been
able to secure a full face portrait from which it would
be difficult to make such a bas-relief. I should be
very grateful indeed in case you have such a photograph
as I speak of, if you would make us a temporary loan
of it. We will take the greatest possible care of it
and will return it to you as soon as possible.

I want to make it clear that the memorial does
not depend upon the bas-relief, but I have the feeling
that it would make the tablet more interesting if we
could place the likeness of Dr. Lazear upon it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Frederick T. van Beuren, Jr., M. D.
Associate Dean. vB/S
